Many AI businesses are searching for moats. A data moat strengthens your defenses if the data is hard to replicate. But if a business offers direct access to a ML model's output (like many LLMs), competitors can use that output as labeled training data, circumventing the moat.While a data moat can be helpful, I find people tend to overestimate its strength. The engineering recipe of training on someone elseâ€™s API output also raises technical, business and legal questions. My longer piece on this in The Batch:

VicuÃ±a features perhaps the most cost-effective approach to LLM, attaining 90+% of the quality of a full ChatGPT, with much less cost ($300!) and carbon footprint. Maybe a personalized LLM at your side assisting wonâ€™t be too far away?

My point is: regulate the product offering (we do this for many things such as medicine, cigarettes, or weapons), but not the research, on LLM; and look beyond just language models, but also foundation models for biology, physics, climate, etc.. There are a lot more values to be unlocked, and a lot less to be feared for.

I attended Andrew Ng and Yann LeCun's talk on the 6-Month AI Pause last week.AI is on everyone's minds and how we can use future applications for business and sales.  Here are the takeaways shared during the talk if you didn't have time to attend:ğŸ”¥ This proposal to halt research is not pragmatic or even implementable. ğŸ”¥ Concerns around ethics, safety, and bias are real, but research is helping these areas. ğŸ”¥ Why should we stop research and halt progress? Regulating products is better than halting research. Â ğŸ”¥ Research has improved AI immensely and has helped us resolve some of the biases.ğŸ”¥ There is such hype around AI right now, but we are NOT that close to human-level intelligence in all the domains.  ğŸ”¥ Language FLUENCY is NOT necessarily intelligence. ğŸ”¥ The panic towards the future is misguided. Â ğŸ”¥Remember Moravec's Paradox: things that appear to be sophisticated are often simple for machines (like chess), but things that appear simple for humans are often very difficult for machines. ğŸ”¥Remember that cars and aviation were once unsafe, and we regulated them and they have become safer and safer for the public. ğŸ”¥The proposal to halt research is not pragmatic or implementable.ğŸ”¥Every time in history that there has been a major breakthrough, the knee-jerk reaction has been fear and trying to stop progress (the printing press, etc.). ğŸ”¥It is concerning that OpenAI pivoted from being an open for researchers and a non-profit to largely a lab for Microsoft, however the proposal is not to have OpenAI open up again. ğŸ”¥ AI escape is not a real risk because AI--unlike humans--does not have a motivation or drive.  ğŸ”¥AI research can assist with regulations.ğŸ”¥Also, AI has great promise and will amplify human intelligence.  ğŸ”¥It is very possible that we will have another Renaissance or another Enlightenment due to AI breakthroughs. Share your thoughts below. ğŸ‘‡ If you would like to listen to the whole talk, I am including the link. Â Â Dr. Andrew Ng an entrepreneur and founder of DeepLearning.AI, an AI and ML researcher, and is a professor at Stanford University. He was the cofounder of Google Brain and was the former Chief Scientist at Baidu, Inc.. Dr. Yan LeCun is a researcher and computer scientist who works in the areas of AI, ML, computational neuroscience, and robotics.  He received the 2018 Turing Award.  He has done research at AT&T Bell Labs and currently the Vice President and Chief AI Scientist at Facebook Meta. #ai #business #chatgpt #sales #technology #future #futurism #share #deeplearning

The surge in launch rates at the principal U.S. launch sites in Florida and California are drawing attention to the urgent need to accelerate transformation of these multi-user spaceports.  The forcing function is the rapidly decreasing cost to orbit.  This excellent graphic from visualcapitalist.com highlights the disruptive impact of SpaceX, a new player making more space applications feasible if not profitable.  I added two trend lines to make the change even more obvious.This trend is irreversible, new players will follow and build upon the SpaceX model or introduce new technologies which will make space access as routine as air is today.  Looking at this graphic it's not hard to believe the current forecasts of launch demand are conservative.

After 15 years as the founder and head of AMD Research, it is time for me to move on. Over the years, AMD Research has created a large number of new technologies for the good of AMD, the compute ecosystem, and humankind. My teams achieved amazing results through individual innovation, strong teamwork, and to quote Newton, by standing on the shoulders of giants.Â Thus, it is with great humility and immense thanks that I dedicate my departing post to all who came before, all my colleagues and friends at AMD, all our collaborators, and all those in the future who will continue to see over the horizon and push out the boundaries of knowledge. Most of all, I would like to thank the engineers and scientists at AMD Research for your creativity and hard work. StartingÂ with 2.5 people and growing into the vibrant organization that exists today, we explored the art of the possible.Â Many more great things to comeâ€¦#AMDResearch #AMD

Please join us tomorrow for a presentation about using deep learning to diagnosis breast cancer hosted by the AI Precision Health Institute  at the University of Hawai'i Cancer Center.This talk we be presented by Krzysztof Geras assistant professor at NYU Grossman School of Medicine of Medicine.Prof Geras' main interests are in unsupervised learning with neural networks, model compression, transfer learning, evaluation of machine learning models and applications of these techniques to medical imaging. In this talk he will describe his 7-year journey in developing deep learning methods for medical imaging, in particular, for breast cancer screening. He will also discuss the limitations and what can likely be achieved in the next few years.Please click the link below to register for the presentation on Zoom.#artificialintelligence  #deeplearning #technology John Shepherd
2d: Today, we're open-sourcing our animated drawings code + releasing a first-of-its-kind dataset of nearly 180,000 annotated amateur drawings to help researchers keep innovating in this space.More details on our blog â¡ï¸ https://bit.ly/3zQwunIRead the paper â¡ï¸ https://bit.ly/3Ut1B2gDrawing as a form of communication is often clear to other humans, but abstract appearances of amateur art can be challenging for AI models trained on real objects. With the new dataset we're releasing today, researchers and practitioners can build tools to more effectively analyze the contents of amateur drawings. We're excited for how this work will open new opportunities in storytelling, accessibility and more.

Not long ago, breakthroughs in AI research often came from lone academics or small teams using desktop hardware. These days, not so much. Are you anxious about how to stay competitive in AI as an academic?Â Georgios N. YannakakisÂ and I wrote this paper for you, as practical advice, therapy session, and discussion starter:https://lnkd.in/efVCYH2hWe outline a number of different things you could do to stay competitive and do relevant, perhaps even important, AI research without having DeepMind-scale resources. It turns out there's actually a lot you can do, but you need to be ready to leave the mainstream and jump off the bandwagon. We also briefly discuss what industrial AI labs and universities can do to improve the situation.An HTML version of our paper can be found here:https://lnkd.in/eHr_X9H5

I'm super excited to share another update on how to optimize Transformer-based models and particularly generative AI models using PyTorch 2 with the publication of our most recent blog about optimizing Generative Diffusion models https://lnkd.in/g4v9qnss.Built from ground up for user experience and performance, PyTorch 2.0 offers out-of-the-box performance improvement for Generative Diffusion models by using the new torch.compile() compiler and Accelerated Transformers (formerly known as 'Better Transformer') with optimized implementations of Multihead Attention integrated with PyTorch 2!Find out more about accelerating Diffusion models in our PyTorch.org blog which you can find here =>https://lnkd.in/g4v9qnssIâ€™m filled with gratitude for the privilege to work with some of the most amazing engineers in our industry at Meta.  A big shout out to the entire PyTorch team at large who builds the framework that enables leading edge research and production, and for building the AI communityâ€™s premier Transformer implementation. Particular kudos go to Grigory Sizov who did amazing work to optimize the diffusion models described here to take advantage of both the high-performance fused attention kernels, and take advantage of torch.compile() while he was still in new hire orientation.Download PyTorch 2 and explore how you can use PyTorch to build better and faster models for your application domains.  Then share how you are using PyTorch, torch.compile and Accelerated Transformers to create high quality models in the comments below.#PyTorch #PyTorch2 #PT2 #AI #GenerativeAI #AcceleratedTransformers #BetterTransformer #AcceleratedAI #accelerators #Meta #MetaAI
